article.headline: LSU 78, Troy State 69
article.story: BATON ROUGE, La. (AP) -- Like any coach three games into a new season, LSU's John Brady feels that his Fighting Tigers still have some things to work on before taking on the tough Southeastern Conference. But Brady certainly wasn't in any mood to complain, especially after the Tigers shot 60 percent from the field in the second half as LSU pulled away to a 78-69 victory over Troy State on Wednesday night. "I knew it would be a fight, because Troy St. have players who can shoot the ball," Brady said. "I don't know if our effort is enough to beat anyone in the SEC yet, but we've definitely gotten better." Jaime Lloreda continued the hot start to his season with a game-high 23 points. Lloreda, who scored 30 points and hauled down a career high 21 rebounds on Monday night against McNeese State, was 8-of-10 from the floor and added seven rebounds. Lloreda, who did not play in either of the Tigers' exhibition game or in the season opener against Southern while serving a suspension, has now scored 20 or more points in back-to-back games for the first time in his career. LSU (3-0) finished with four players in double figures. Antonio Hudson finished in double figures for the third consecutive game with 15 points, followed by Darrell Mitchell with 13 and Xavier Whipple with 11. Brandon Bass led LSU with 11 rebounds and helped the Tigers finish with a 35-28 edge on the glass. "We never got out of the game, and I thought it was a hard-fought basketball game," Troy St. coach Don Maestri said. "LSU is a very good basketball team that has a lot of talent, and they will contend for the SEC title." Troy St. (1-1) took a 34-31 lead early in the second half on an up and under layup by Greg Davis, but LSU took the lead back at 37-35 on an Hudson 3-pointer. Troy St. would answer with a 3-pointer from Kendrick Johnson to make it 39-38, but after that basket, the Tigers took command of the contest with a 16-2 run in a five-minute stretch.

statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.
